'''Michael Selwyn Longuet-Higgins''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 1925) is a mathematician and [[oceanographer]] at Institute for Nonlinear Science, [[University of California, San Diego]]. He is the younger brother of [[H. Christopher Longuet-Higgins]].

Longuet-Higgins introduced the theory of the origin of [[microseism]]s<ref>{{cite journal| author=Longuet-Higgins, M. S. | title=A theory of the origin of microseisms| journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A]] | volume = 243| year=1950 | pages=1–35 | doi=10.1098/rsta.1950.0012|bibcode = 1950RSPTA.243....1L }}</ref> and is the inventor of [[Rhombo blocks]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Rhombo blocks on my pentagonal coffee table | publisher= | url = http://www.cs.purdue.edu/homes/gnf/book/Booknews/rhomb.html | accessdate = 2008-09-19 }}</ref>

==Education and career==
Longuet-Higgins studied at [[Winchester College]] with [[Freeman Dyson]] from 1937 to 1941. He graduated in mathematics from the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1946, with a Ph.D. in [[geophysics]] in 1951. From 1969 to 1989 he served as a [[Royal Society]] Research Professor at the University of Cambridge. 

His research areas include both [[pure mathematics]] ([[projective geometry]], [[polytopes]], random functions and
surfaces) and applied mathematics ([[fluid dynamics]], microseisms, the generation of ocean waves by wind, the dynamics of [[Liquid bubble|bubbles]], [[sonoluminescence]], [[wave breaking]], and steep waves).

==Personal==
His recreations include [[music]], [[gardening]], and [[educational toys]]: in 1953 he wrote a scientific paper on the properties of the [[Slinky]].<ref name="On Slinky: the dynamics of a loose, heavy spring">{{cite web|last1=Longuet-Higgins|first1=Michael|title=On Slinky: the dynamics of a loose, heavy spring|url=http://www2.eng.cam.ac.uk/~hemh/TV/On_Slinky_the_dynamics_of_a_loose_heavy_spring.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref> He is widowed, with four children.
